definitions_glossary.planck_time: The fundamental timescale √(ℏG/c⁵) ≈ 5.4 × 10⁻⁴⁴ s at which quantum gravity effects dominate
definitions_glossary.planck_epoch: The earliest period in cosmic history (0 < t < tₚ) where quantum gravitational effects dominated the universe
definitions_glossary.light_travel_time: The time required for light to traverse a given distance in vacuum
definitions_glossary.quantum_fluctuations: Temporary changes in energy and other quantities that occur due to Heisenberg's uncertainty principle
definitions_glossary.metric_tensor: The mathematical object g_μν describing the geometry of spacetime in general relativity
definitions_glossary.causality: The relationship between cause and effect; signals cannot propagate faster than light
definitions_glossary.spacetime_geometry: The curved four-dimensional structure combining space and time as described by general relativity

key_relationships.description: Light travel time across one Planck length
Distance light travels in one Planck time equals Planck length

scale_comparisons.description: Planck time is 20 orders of magnitude shorter than atomic transition times (~10⁻¹⁸ s)
The universe has existed for ~10⁶⁰ Planck times
Modern electronics operate on nanosecond timescales, 10³⁰ times longer

definition.@value: The fundamental timescale √(ℏG/c⁵) ≈ 5.391 × 10⁻⁴⁴ s representing the shortest time interval with physical meaning, equal to the light-travel time across one Planck length

scopeNote.@value: Essential for cosmology of the early universe, quantum gravity theories, and understanding temporal limits of current physical theories

related.relationship: Planck time = Planck length / speed of light
Energy-time uncertainty relation at Planck scale

learning_objectives: Define Planck time and understand its relationship to Planck length
Explain the physical significance for early universe cosmology
Understand why temporal measurements become uncertain below tₚ
Recognize the Planck epoch as the boundary of known physics
Apply Planck time in quantum gravity and cosmology contexts
common_errors: Thinking Planck time represents a 'frame rate' of reality (continuity of time not proven discrete)
Confusing Planck time with Planck era in cosmology (era extends from 0 to ~tₚ)
Assuming nothing can happen faster than Planck time (theory limitations, not prohibition)
physics_insights: The relation tₚ = ℓₚ/c connects spatial and temporal Planck scales via fundamental speed limit
Energy-time uncertainty ΔE·Δt ≥ ℏ/2 at Planck scale gives ΔE ~ Eₚ for Δt ~ tₚ
In the early universe, t = tₚ marks when quantum gravity effects became subdominant
Loop quantum gravity suggests spacetime may have discrete structure at tₚ timescale
